YRICINS

University Will Move to New Site Next
October,Says Pres. Goodnow -Old
Laboratories to be Used.

The Johns Hopkins University
will move to Homewood on October 1, 1916.
This statement was made for the
first time last week, and was (riven
to a representative of the ''THE
NEWS-LETTER by President Goodnow.
The University has been agitated
for over a year by rumors of immediate removal, of removal indefinitely postponed, and of removal
scheduled for anywhere within two
to ten years. With the advent of
President Goodnow speculation increased, and despite the statement
of Mr. R. Brent Keyser, made
earlier in the year, that there was
practically no chance of Hopkins
moving out to Homewood in 1915,
within the last two months .a new
report has been circulated almost
every day.
The statement of President Goodnow has settled once for all the
suspense which has pervaded Hopkins ever since it was definitely
known that I romewood was to be
the University's future home. It
is an announcement which will be
enthusiastically welcomed by every
Hopkins student and every Hopkins
alumnus.
The date is definite and final.
There are I10 conditions to be fulfilled or developments to be awaited;
unless something occurs which is
entirely outside of the range of
probable events, Hopkins will be at
Homewood in 1916.
President Goodnow stated that it
is doubtful, if, at the time of removal, any more buildings will be
standing at Homewood than are
there at the present time. The
laboratories at the present site will
be used ; but the President declared
that this will in no wax' interfere
with the work of the University.
The only building which is at all
likely to be erected before 1916 is
the Chemical Laboratory and the
building of this structure before
that date is highly provisional. It
depends, in fact, upon the chances
of any gifts being made to the University within the course of next
year.
The President stated emphatically
that the present financial condition
of the University would not permit
of any new buildings being erected
before removal, and that all hopes
of some structures at Homewood
before 1916 depended upon the
generosity of the public.
The fact that the laboratories on
Monument street will be used in no
way lessens the importance of President Goodnow's announcement.

PARTICIPANTS IN INAUGURATION
TO MARCH IN ACADEMIC COSTUME
Faculty, Boards of Trustees, Representatives of Other
Institutions, and Graduate Students Will Form
Academic Procession on Thursday, May 20.

PROCESSION

The Trustees and Faculty of the University, and the representatives
of other colleges and universities, will form in line in the Engineering
Building, and will march to the terrace immediately in front of the
Academic Building.
The procession will form in the main corridor of the Engineering
Building at four o'clock, the preliminary places of gathering in the
building being as follows:
President and Boards of Trustees of the University, and of the Hospital and recipients of Honorary Degrees: Professor Mathews, marshal;
Room log.
_.
Faculty: Dr. Magoffin, marshal; Room Kn.
Representatives of other Institutions: Professor Tilden, marshal;
Room r io.
Academic costume is expected of all who march in the last two
divisions. Plain caps and gowns, but not hoods, may be rented by applicaiion in advance to the Registrar.
NOTICES

The Academic procession will be preceded by a procession of the
alumni, graduate and medical students of the University. This procession
will form on the second floor of the Engineering Building at three-thirty
o'clock. Placards will indicate the place of assembly for each group.
Individual tickets of admission will be sent to the ladies of the
immediate families of members of the -Boards of Trustees of the University and of the Hospital, and of the Faculty of the University. These
tickets will admit bearers •to a reserved section at a special entrance
lettered F. No seats will be reserved after a quarter past four o'clock.
On Friday morning at ten o'clock there will be given in the laboratories of the University, including those of the Medical School, illustrative exercises of special interest to the alumni.
On Friday, May 21, at eight P. M., the Engineering Laboratories and
the Power Plant will be open for inspection. There will be short explanatory addresses by members of the Faculty of Engineering at eightfifteen in the main lecture room.
Carriages and automobiles must be parked on Thirty-second and
Thirty-third streets, where watchmen will be stationed. Messenger service between these points and the Academic Building will be supplied
by Troop 16 of the Boy Scouts. Fifteen minutes should be allowed after
the evening reception for cars to be brought into the line.
In case of showers, the afternoon exercises will be held in the
Academic Building, where reservation can be made for the procession
only. In case of protracted rain, special arrangements will be made at
the Lyric or. elsewhere, notice of which will be posted at the University,
at the principal hotels, at the intersection of Charles street and North
avenue, and at other prominent points.
Saturday will be Alumni Day. In the afternoon there will be a
lacrosse game at Homewood, and in the evening a banquet at the Hotel
Emerson. On Friday evening, at nine o'clock, the Johns Hopkins Club
will give a smoker to the alumni and former students of the University.

MAY 12, 1915.

MURRAY PEABODY BRUSH,
Chief Marshal.

BLACK AND BLUE FINISHES
BY DEFEATING ST. JOHN'S
Defandorf Pitches Great Ball, but Is Supported Raggedly at Times Worthington Stars Getting Double
and Triple.

With the whole team playing at
its best and with jack Defandorf.
pitching the game of his life, Hopkins defeated St. John's on Saturday afternoon, in a close, wellplayed game. Until the eighth inning the 'Varsity led St. John's 4
to o, but at the very last the Soldiers
took a brace and were able to push
one run over in the eighth, and two
more in the ninth. Then Defandorf
settled down and ended the game
by striking out the last batter.
Bill Noble, who has helped Hopkins will so many of its games this
year by his catching and wonderful
hitting, was not in the line-up; but
Roger Howell, who was shifted
from first to behind the bat caught
a very good game.
This victory gives Hopkins a
claim on the State championship, as
all their defeats this season have
been at the hands of teams from
other States. The Black and Blue
started the game with a rush,
pushing three runs over in the
second inning. Ewing walked.
Lednutri sent a pop fly to third and
Ewing stole second. Then after
Egerton had struck out, Howell
came through with a single to center, scoring Ewing. Defandorf was
safe on a hit back of second.
Worthington then pushed over two
more runs with a three-bagger, but
he was nabbed at the plate trying to
stretch the hit into a homer.
Ewing really made a homer in
the fourth, but was called out for
not touching second.
Defandorf allowed only four hits
and if his teammates could have
fielded in perfect style behind him
he would have scored a shut-out.

Members of the Garden Clubs of
America were entertained Tuesday
evening, in McCoy Hall, by the
Municipal Art Society of Baltimore,
when Mr. Thomas Shields Clarke
gave an illustrated lecture on "Garden Pictures in Color."
The pictures were wonderfully
colored, showing flowers and gardens, and catching the shadings and
tints, with an exactness approaching perfection. A large estate is
not necessary, explained Mr.
Clarke, in order to have such beauty
spots about the home, and he
showed many gardens of small size
that, in the charm of their arrangement and coloring, were "horticultural poems."
Several of the gardens displayed
were of the formal Italian garden
type, but those which won the most
enthusiastic applause were those
that seemed to be "bits of wild
woodland flower beds brought
home to grow." After the lecture
an informal reception was held and
refreshments served.
The Garden Clubs of America
have been holding their annual
meeting in Baltimore. Reports of
work accomplished in other cities
were read, gardens were visited,
and the one evening was devoted
to visiting some of the beautiful
gardens of the country by means
of pictures.
Mr. Clarke is a sculptor and
painter of note, has studied in Europe, and has won numerous medals
at the world's expositions. He has
executed many large works in
bronze and marble, and his pictures
are exhibited in several of the large
galleries throughout the country.

The last meeting of the Adams
Literary Society for this year was
held last Thursday at one o'clock,
and was devoted to a discussion of
Plans for the future.
It was decided that owing to the
inauguration exercises and to the
nearness of the final examinations,
it would be useless to enter into
any literary exercises for the remainder of this term. The Board
of Curators, however, consisting of
Hooper and Chalmers, announced
that formal programs would be
made up immediately after the
summer vacation was over.
Suggestions were then offered in
regard to the debates with other
colleges which are to form such a
large part of the Adams' work.
The question of whether it was advisable to schedule any debates during the summer months was first
taken up, and, the Society having
decided that the work should be
undertaken immediately, a debate
committee consisting of Tingley,
chairman; Steinbach and Oppenheimer was elected.
This committee NV11I immediately
begin to arrange for several debates with college societies, to be
held during the course of next year.
One debate, that with the Zelosophic Society of the University
of Pennsylvania, has been inherited
from the old Grotius Society; and
the committee expects to have no
difficulty in scheduling as many
more debates as the finances and
inclination of the Society will permit.
Before the meeting adjourned,
Smith was appointed to serve on the
Membership Committee in place of
Oppenheimer, who had resigned
owing to a clause in the constituCLASS OF 1913 TO HOLD

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 17, 1915.
UNDERCLASS TEAMS AT WORK

TENNIS TOURNAMENT ANNOUNCED

Freshman and Sophomore Baseball
Squads Hold Regular Practices in
Preparation for Game, May 19.

Contest to Begin on Homewood Courts,
May 17—Many Promising Players to
Enter—Morgan Picked to Win.

The Freshman baseball squad
held its first organized practice on
Saturday, May 8, at Homewood.
The practice was lively, and keen
competition was exhibited. The
squad is composed of many good
men, practically all of whom have
played on scholastic teams, and
many of them being ex-captains.
The freshmen are particularly
strong in the pitching- line, having
six available pitchers, every one of
whom is making a strong bid for
supremacy. The problem of selecting the best man for the rubber
will therefore be exceedingly difficult. The pitching staff so far consists of Love,Taylor,Witz, Hollingsworth, Rolker and Cromwell. The
candidates for the infield are Egerton, Chalmers, Woodward, Hoffman, Pepper, Sullivan, Cort, Randall, Adams and Evans. Only two
catchers, M. J. Cromwell and
Ewing, have so far reported. Candidates for the outfield are Jacobsen, Kohn, Adams, Sullivan, Miller,
Nelson, Rosenau and Thurman.
Judging from appearances, the
Freshman-Sophomore game, scheduled for May 19, will be hotly contested. The freshmen apparently
have a slight advantage over their
rivals, but the sophomores will be
out for blood, in revenge for their
stinging defeat of 20-0 in football,
at the hands of the freshmen.
"Eggie" Gorman is the manager of
the sophomore team, and "Jack"
Defandorf is the captain. These
two, both being 'Varsity pitchers,
bid fair to make the freshmen batters hustle. The freshmen have
elected Chalmers manager, and
Randall captain of their team.

The annual spring tennis tournament starts on Monday, May 17.
This contest is open to all students
of the University; and if the interest displayed in this event in
past seasons is considered, as well
as the large number of good tennis
players in the freshman and sophomore classes, this year's tournament
bids fair to surpass all others in the
number of the entrants and the
closeness of the play.
A. L. Hammond, W. S. Merrick, T. J. Binford, E. R. Roach
and W. C. Taylor, who are in
charge of the tournament, have announced that prizes will be given
the winner and runner-up in the
singles, the winners in the doubles,
and the winner in the consolation
singles. There is an entrance fee
of fifty cents to cover the cost of
balls and prizes.
Morgan, the medical student who
has been Hopkins' standby on the
courts for several years, is picked
to repeat his past performances, and
again win the tournament. He will
not have an easy time, however,
for there are several new men at the
University this year who have displayed such speed and ability that
Morgan will have to bring into play
all the tennis he knows in order to

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 17, 1915.
The Spring Athletics.

With the defeat of St. John's last
Saturday the 'Varsity baseball team
brought to a close a most successful season. Under the guidance of Coach Hooper, and the leadership of Captain Porter, the candidates have rounded out this year
into a team which has clearly shown
that baseball is rapidly becoming
one of the most important sports at
Johns Hopkins. Coach Hooper is
to be congratulated on the excellent
work he has done with the men.
It was largely through his efforts
that the team won the championship
of the State.
Hopkins' most noted athletic
achievement, however, was the winning of the lacrosse championship
of the United States. Lacrosse has
for several years been the one.
branch of athletics in which Johns
Hopkins has been able to cope with
teams from larger northern colleges, and the fact that the team is
able to make a good record for itself each season is a point worthy
of favorable note.
The track team, although it was
hampered at the outset by a marked
lack of material, has, nevertheless,
shown up very well in most of its
'meets, and has finished its season
in p. highly creditable manner. The
team was, with few exceptions,
made up of new men, and the train• ing of the "green" material presented to Coach England no mean
task. However, the track men, as
well as the baseball and lacrosse
men, are distinctly to be congratulated on their work this season. It
has been a most prosperous athletic
season -in -every.-way.-

Final Preparation for Ceremonies Made.
Nearly all Invitations Answered- Undergraduates to Act as Ushers.

All plans and arrangements for
the inauguration of President Goodnow and the dedication of the Technical School and of Gilman Hall
have now been fully completed, and
the eventful close of this week is
being awaited with a large degree
of interest by all who are connected
with the University.
Nearly all of the invitations issued by those in charge of the exercises have been answered, and the
presence of a large number of
prominent men from all parts of the
country is assured. The Committee on Arrangements is confident
that the program that lias been prepared will be most successfully carried out in every detail.
It is sincerely hoped that the students of the University, and especially the undergraduates, as they
alone will be dismissed from their
regular classes, will manifest their
interest in the exercises by volunteering as ushers on Thursday and
Friday. The ushers will be expected to wear white trousers, a black
Or blue coat, windsor tie, and black
shoes. No special arrangements
will be made for the accommodation of the students who do not
volunteer to act in this official capacity, and they will thus be compelled to find seats in the section of
The stand that has been reserved for
the general public. The services of
a large number will, however, be
required to assist in the carrying
out of the program of the first two
days, and Allen F. Voshell, of the
Senior Class, who is in charge of
the arrangements that are being
made for student participation in
the exercises, will be glad to receive the names of any volunteers.
Dr. Ralph Van D. Magoffin,
secretary of the Committee on Arrangements, has expressed the desire that as many students as possible shall wear the thoroughly appropriate and seasonal uniform that
has been prescribed for the ushers.
Such a concerted action would undoubtedly add greatly to the dignity and the official character of the
occasion, and would be a thoroughly fitting manifestation of the
general interest that is being taken
ill the affair. The fact that two
hundred wands, • decorated with
black and blue ribbons, are being
prepared for the ushers to use as
signs of office, and to retain, if they
so desire, as souvenirs, is a sufficient
indication that the hearty co-operation of undergraduates is earnestly desired by those in charge of the
exercises, and that every student of
the. University is expected to take
some part in the program which
they have prepared.

Connolly, Hall and Straus to Go to the
Northern Intercollegiates.

In the election held by the track
team immediately after the meet
last Saturday, Fred. Hall, '17, was
unanimously elected captain for
next year. Hall has made a good
record this year, running as anchorman on the relay team, and winning
first place in the indoor South Atlantic Championship 88o-yard run.
and second place in the outdoor
event. He had some experience at
the game before coming to Hopkins, as point-winner on the track
team of the Tonle School. He has
two more years at Hopkins and is
showing steady improvement.
It was announced Saturday that
Connolly, Hall and Straus will be
the men from the team to go this
year to the Northern Intercollegiate Championships, which will be
held at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, May 28 and 29. Hopkins is
the only member of the Southern
association to belong to the Northern division, and each year she
sends the three men required to
hold membership.
Last year
"Freddy" Lee, in the beautiful
world-record making two-mile race,
placed and secured a point for Hopkins after leading the race for seven
and a-half laps. It was hoped that
Ben Tappan would be able to go this
year, but he will have to remain in
town at • the time, on account of
final examinations at the Medical
School.
Hullabaloo Nearly Ready.

The 1915 Hullabaloo Board announces that most of the proof
reading of the book has been done,
and that the book will probably be
distributed about the twentieth of
this month. Business Manager
Spencer announced last week that
those who want a copy of the book
must order it at once if they have
not already done so. The number
of books to be printed is to be absolutely limited.
A very noticeable feature of this
year's Hullabaloo is the use of a
new style of type. This makes the
book distinctly different from those
of former years. A number of cuts
of the new buildings at Homewood
will form an interesting feature of
the annual.

*

*

*

The Trinity College Y. M. C. A.
is raising money to put an ambulance in the war zone. They already have over two hundred dollars pledged.
.\1. I. T. has instituted this year
the carrying on of "fraternity
forums." Four of the fraternities
have had successful business men
of Boston give them informal talks.
The students of Syracuse University are planting trees on their
campus. Fifty men work at a time
under the supervision of some of
the instructors.
* * *
Northwestern College freshmen
are still permitted to cover their
heads according to their own individual tastes. But the Student
Council has recently written to
some of the other colleges to make
inquiries into the advisability of instituting a freshman cap rtile.
Green skull caps will probably be
prescribed.
* * *
Students at Michigan Agricultural College are considering a
Class Constitution, embodying all
the present customs of class government. This is a good measure,
calculated to do away with confusion and to standardize procedure. and would do well here.

Ben Tappan, who appeared for
.his last time, as he is completing his
eighth year at the University, and
receives his degree in medicine this
June, once again starred brilliantly,
winning 22 points in five events.
He took first place in the 120-yard
hurdles in 16.seconds; first place in
the pole vault at 10 feet; first place
in the broad jump with 22 feet iY2
inches; tied for first with Captain
Connolly in the high jump, at 5 feet
inches, and took second place in
the low hurdles, won by Schultz,
W. and L., in 26 seconds. This
completes a wonderful record in
scoring for Tappan, who has placed
in every event he has entered this
year, and made a total of nearly
ioo points in seven meets. He will
be sorely missed next year.
Fred.' Hall, of Hopkins, was the
second figure in brilliance. He
made tell points by winning both the
quarter and the half-mile.

and to see him at last win a clear
victory and his "H," was a, great

49 seconds.

run, for the three competitors got
so widely separated that there was

made seven points. He is.suffering

YRICINS

University Will Move to New Site Next
October,Says Pres. Goodnow -Old
Laboratories to be Used.

The Johns Hopkins University
will move to Homewood on October 1, 1916.
This statement was made for the
first time last week, and was (riven
to a representative of the ''THE
NEWS-LETTER by President Goodnow.
The University has been agitated
for over a year by rumors of immediate removal, of removal indefinitely postponed, and of removal
scheduled for anywhere within two
to ten years. With the advent of
President Goodnow speculation increased, and despite the statement
of Mr. R. Brent Keyser, made
earlier in the year, that there was
practically no chance of Hopkins
moving out to Homewood in 1915,
within the last two months .a new
report has been circulated almost
every day.
The statement of President Goodnow has settled once for all the
suspense which has pervaded Hopkins ever since it was definitely
known that I romewood was to be
the University's future home. It
is an announcement which will be
enthusiastically welcomed by every
Hopkins student and every Hopkins
alumnus.
The date is definite and final.
There are I10 conditions to be fulfilled or developments to be awaited;
unless something occurs which is
entirely outside of the range of
probable events, Hopkins will be at
Homewood in 1916.
President Goodnow stated that it
is doubtful, if, at the time of removal, any more buildings will be
standing at Homewood than are
there at the present time. The
laboratories at the present site will
be used ; but the President declared
that this will in no wax' interfere
with the work of the University.
The only building which is at all
likely to be erected before 1916 is
the Chemical Laboratory and the
building of this structure before
that date is highly provisional. It
depends, in fact, upon the chances
of any gifts being made to the University within the course of next
year.
The President stated emphatically
that the present financial condition
of the University would not permit
of any new buildings being erected
before removal, and that all hopes
of some structures at Homewood
before 1916 depended upon the
generosity of the public.
The fact that the laboratories on
Monument street will be used in no
way lessens the importance of President Goodnow's announcement.

PARTICIPANTS IN INAUGURATION
TO MARCH IN ACADEMIC COSTUME
Faculty, Boards of Trustees, Representatives of Other
Institutions, and Graduate Students Will Form
Academic Procession on Thursday, May 20.

PROCESSION

The Trustees and Faculty of the University, and the representatives
of other colleges and universities, will form in line in the Engineering
Building, and will march to the terrace immediately in front of the
Academic Building.
The procession will form in the main corridor of the Engineering
Building at four o'clock, the preliminary places of gathering in the
building being as follows:
President and Boards of Trustees of the University, and of the Hospital and recipients of Honorary Degrees: Professor Mathews, marshal;
Room log.
_.
Faculty: Dr. Magoffin, marshal; Room Kn.
Representatives of other Institutions: Professor Tilden, marshal;
Room r io.
Academic costume is expected of all who march in the last two
divisions. Plain caps and gowns, but not hoods, may be rented by applicaiion in advance to the Registrar.
NOTICES

The Academic procession will be preceded by a procession of the
alumni, graduate and medical students of the University. This procession
will form on the second floor of the Engineering Building at three-thirty
o'clock. Placards will indicate the place of assembly for each group.
Individual tickets of admission will be sent to the ladies of the
immediate families of members of the -Boards of Trustees of the University and of the Hospital, and of the Faculty of the University. These
tickets will admit bearers •to a reserved section at a special entrance
lettered F. No seats will be reserved after a quarter past four o'clock.
On Friday morning at ten o'clock there will be given in the laboratories of the University, including those of the Medical School, illustrative exercises of special interest to the alumni.
On Friday, May 21, at eight P. M., the Engineering Laboratories and
the Power Plant will be open for inspection. There will be short explanatory addresses by members of the Faculty of Engineering at eightfifteen in the main lecture room.
Carriages and automobiles must be parked on Thirty-second and
Thirty-third streets, where watchmen will be stationed. Messenger service between these points and the Academic Building will be supplied
by Troop 16 of the Boy Scouts. Fifteen minutes should be allowed after
the evening reception for cars to be brought into the line.
In case of showers, the afternoon exercises will be held in the
Academic Building, where reservation can be made for the procession
only. In case of protracted rain, special arrangements will be made at
the Lyric or. elsewhere, notice of which will be posted at the University,
at the principal hotels, at the intersection of Charles street and North
avenue, and at other prominent points.
Saturday will be Alumni Day. In the afternoon there will be a
lacrosse game at Homewood, and in the evening a banquet at the Hotel
Emerson. On Friday evening, at nine o'clock, the Johns Hopkins Club
will give a smoker to the alumni and former students of the University.

MAY 12, 1915.

MURRAY PEABODY BRUSH,
Chief Marshal.

BLACK AND BLUE FINISHES
BY DEFEATING ST. JOHN'S
Defandorf Pitches Great Ball, but Is Supported Raggedly at Times Worthington Stars Getting Double
and Triple.

With the whole team playing at
its best and with jack Defandorf.
pitching the game of his life, Hopkins defeated St. John's on Saturday afternoon, in a close, wellplayed game. Until the eighth inning the 'Varsity led St. John's 4
to o, but at the very last the Soldiers
took a brace and were able to push
one run over in the eighth, and two
more in the ninth. Then Defandorf
settled down and ended the game
by striking out the last batter.
Bill Noble, who has helped Hopkins will so many of its games this
year by his catching and wonderful
hitting, was not in the line-up; but
Roger Howell, who was shifted
from first to behind the bat caught
a very good game.
This victory gives Hopkins a
claim on the State championship, as
all their defeats this season have
been at the hands of teams from
other States. The Black and Blue
started the game with a rush,
pushing three runs over in the
second inning. Ewing walked.
Lednutri sent a pop fly to third and
Ewing stole second. Then after
Egerton had struck out, Howell
came through with a single to center, scoring Ewing. Defandorf was
safe on a hit back of second.
Worthington then pushed over two
more runs with a three-bagger, but
he was nabbed at the plate trying to
stretch the hit into a homer.
Ewing really made a homer in
the fourth, but was called out for
not touching second.
Defandorf allowed only four hits
and if his teammates could have
fielded in perfect style behind him
he would have scored a shut-out.

Members of the Garden Clubs of
America were entertained Tuesday
evening, in McCoy Hall, by the
Municipal Art Society of Baltimore,
when Mr. Thomas Shields Clarke
gave an illustrated lecture on "Garden Pictures in Color."
The pictures were wonderfully
colored, showing flowers and gardens, and catching the shadings and
tints, with an exactness approaching perfection. A large estate is
not necessary, explained Mr.
Clarke, in order to have such beauty
spots about the home, and he
showed many gardens of small size
that, in the charm of their arrangement and coloring, were "horticultural poems."
Several of the gardens displayed
were of the formal Italian garden
type, but those which won the most
enthusiastic applause were those
that seemed to be "bits of wild
woodland flower beds brought
home to grow." After the lecture
an informal reception was held and
refreshments served.
The Garden Clubs of America
have been holding their annual
meeting in Baltimore. Reports of
work accomplished in other cities
were read, gardens were visited,
and the one evening was devoted
to visiting some of the beautiful
gardens of the country by means
of pictures.
Mr. Clarke is a sculptor and
painter of note, has studied in Europe, and has won numerous medals
at the world's expositions. He has
executed many large works in
bronze and marble, and his pictures
are exhibited in several of the large
galleries throughout the country.

The last meeting of the Adams
Literary Society for this year was
held last Thursday at one o'clock,
and was devoted to a discussion of
Plans for the future.
It was decided that owing to the
inauguration exercises and to the
nearness of the final examinations,
it would be useless to enter into
any literary exercises for the remainder of this term. The Board
of Curators, however, consisting of
Hooper and Chalmers, announced
that formal programs would be
made up immediately after the
summer vacation was over.
Suggestions were then offered in
regard to the debates with other
colleges which are to form such a
large part of the Adams' work.
The question of whether it was advisable to schedule any debates during the summer months was first
taken up, and, the Society having
decided that the work should be
undertaken immediately, a debate
committee consisting of Tingley,
chairman; Steinbach and Oppenheimer was elected.
This committee NV11I immediately
begin to arrange for several debates with college societies, to be
held during the course of next year.
One debate, that with the Zelosophic Society of the University
of Pennsylvania, has been inherited
from the old Grotius Society; and
the committee expects to have no
difficulty in scheduling as many
more debates as the finances and
inclination of the Society will permit.
Before the meeting adjourned,
Smith was appointed to serve on the
Membership Committee in place of
Oppenheimer, who had resigned
owing to a clause in the constituCLASS OF 1913 TO HOLD

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 17, 1915.
UNDERCLASS TEAMS AT WORK

TENNIS TOURNAMENT ANNOUNCED

Freshman and Sophomore Baseball
Squads Hold Regular Practices in
Preparation for Game, May 19.

Contest to Begin on Homewood Courts,
May 17—Many Promising Players to
Enter—Morgan Picked to Win.

The Freshman baseball squad
held its first organized practice on
Saturday, May 8, at Homewood.
The practice was lively, and keen
competition was exhibited. The
squad is composed of many good
men, practically all of whom have
played on scholastic teams, and
many of them being ex-captains.
The freshmen are particularly
strong in the pitching- line, having
six available pitchers, every one of
whom is making a strong bid for
supremacy. The problem of selecting the best man for the rubber
will therefore be exceedingly difficult. The pitching staff so far consists of Love,Taylor,Witz, Hollingsworth, Rolker and Cromwell. The
candidates for the infield are Egerton, Chalmers, Woodward, Hoffman, Pepper, Sullivan, Cort, Randall, Adams and Evans. Only two
catchers, M. J. Cromwell and
Ewing, have so far reported. Candidates for the outfield are Jacobsen, Kohn, Adams, Sullivan, Miller,
Nelson, Rosenau and Thurman.
Judging from appearances, the
Freshman-Sophomore game, scheduled for May 19, will be hotly contested. The freshmen apparently
have a slight advantage over their
rivals, but the sophomores will be
out for blood, in revenge for their
stinging defeat of 20-0 in football,
at the hands of the freshmen.
"Eggie" Gorman is the manager of
the sophomore team, and "Jack"
Defandorf is the captain. These
two, both being 'Varsity pitchers,
bid fair to make the freshmen batters hustle. The freshmen have
elected Chalmers manager, and
Randall captain of their team.

The annual spring tennis tournament starts on Monday, May 17.
This contest is open to all students
of the University; and if the interest displayed in this event in
past seasons is considered, as well
as the large number of good tennis
players in the freshman and sophomore classes, this year's tournament
bids fair to surpass all others in the
number of the entrants and the
closeness of the play.
A. L. Hammond, W. S. Merrick, T. J. Binford, E. R. Roach
and W. C. Taylor, who are in
charge of the tournament, have announced that prizes will be given
the winner and runner-up in the
singles, the winners in the doubles,
and the winner in the consolation
singles. There is an entrance fee
of fifty cents to cover the cost of
balls and prizes.
Morgan, the medical student who
has been Hopkins' standby on the
courts for several years, is picked
to repeat his past performances, and
again win the tournament. He will
not have an easy time, however,
for there are several new men at the
University this year who have displayed such speed and ability that
Morgan will have to bring into play
all the tennis he knows in order to

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 17, 1915.
The Spring Athletics.

With the defeat of St. John's last
Saturday the 'Varsity baseball team
brought to a close a most successful season. Under the guidance of Coach Hooper, and the leadership of Captain Porter, the candidates have rounded out this year
into a team which has clearly shown
that baseball is rapidly becoming
one of the most important sports at
Johns Hopkins. Coach Hooper is
to be congratulated on the excellent
work he has done with the men.
It was largely through his efforts
that the team won the championship
of the State.
Hopkins' most noted athletic
achievement, however, was the winning of the lacrosse championship
of the United States. Lacrosse has
for several years been the one.
branch of athletics in which Johns
Hopkins has been able to cope with
teams from larger northern colleges, and the fact that the team is
able to make a good record for itself each season is a point worthy
of favorable note.
The track team, although it was
hampered at the outset by a marked
lack of material, has, nevertheless,
shown up very well in most of its
'meets, and has finished its season
in p. highly creditable manner. The
team was, with few exceptions,
made up of new men, and the train• ing of the "green" material presented to Coach England no mean
task. However, the track men, as
well as the baseball and lacrosse
men, are distinctly to be congratulated on their work this season. It
has been a most prosperous athletic
season -in -every.-way.-

Final Preparation for Ceremonies Made.
Nearly all Invitations Answered- Undergraduates to Act as Ushers.

All plans and arrangements for
the inauguration of President Goodnow and the dedication of the Technical School and of Gilman Hall
have now been fully completed, and
the eventful close of this week is
being awaited with a large degree
of interest by all who are connected
with the University.
Nearly all of the invitations issued by those in charge of the exercises have been answered, and the
presence of a large number of
prominent men from all parts of the
country is assured. The Committee on Arrangements is confident
that the program that lias been prepared will be most successfully carried out in every detail.
It is sincerely hoped that the students of the University, and especially the undergraduates, as they
alone will be dismissed from their
regular classes, will manifest their
interest in the exercises by volunteering as ushers on Thursday and
Friday. The ushers will be expected to wear white trousers, a black
Or blue coat, windsor tie, and black
shoes. No special arrangements
will be made for the accommodation of the students who do not
volunteer to act in this official capacity, and they will thus be compelled to find seats in the section of
The stand that has been reserved for
the general public. The services of
a large number will, however, be
required to assist in the carrying
out of the program of the first two
days, and Allen F. Voshell, of the
Senior Class, who is in charge of
the arrangements that are being
made for student participation in
the exercises, will be glad to receive the names of any volunteers.
Dr. Ralph Van D. Magoffin,
secretary of the Committee on Arrangements, has expressed the desire that as many students as possible shall wear the thoroughly appropriate and seasonal uniform that
has been prescribed for the ushers.
Such a concerted action would undoubtedly add greatly to the dignity and the official character of the
occasion, and would be a thoroughly fitting manifestation of the
general interest that is being taken
ill the affair. The fact that two
hundred wands, • decorated with
black and blue ribbons, are being
prepared for the ushers to use as
signs of office, and to retain, if they
so desire, as souvenirs, is a sufficient
indication that the hearty co-operation of undergraduates is earnestly desired by those in charge of the
exercises, and that every student of
the. University is expected to take
some part in the program which
they have prepared.

Connolly, Hall and Straus to Go to the
Northern Intercollegiates.

In the election held by the track
team immediately after the meet
last Saturday, Fred. Hall, '17, was
unanimously elected captain for
next year. Hall has made a good
record this year, running as anchorman on the relay team, and winning
first place in the indoor South Atlantic Championship 88o-yard run.
and second place in the outdoor
event. He had some experience at
the game before coming to Hopkins, as point-winner on the track
team of the Tonle School. He has
two more years at Hopkins and is
showing steady improvement.
It was announced Saturday that
Connolly, Hall and Straus will be
the men from the team to go this
year to the Northern Intercollegiate Championships, which will be
held at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, May 28 and 29. Hopkins is
the only member of the Southern
association to belong to the Northern division, and each year she
sends the three men required to
hold membership.
Last year
"Freddy" Lee, in the beautiful
world-record making two-mile race,
placed and secured a point for Hopkins after leading the race for seven
and a-half laps. It was hoped that
Ben Tappan would be able to go this
year, but he will have to remain in
town at • the time, on account of
final examinations at the Medical
School.
Hullabaloo Nearly Ready.

The 1915 Hullabaloo Board announces that most of the proof
reading of the book has been done,
and that the book will probably be
distributed about the twentieth of
this month. Business Manager
Spencer announced last week that
those who want a copy of the book
must order it at once if they have
not already done so. The number
of books to be printed is to be absolutely limited.
A very noticeable feature of this
year's Hullabaloo is the use of a
new style of type. This makes the
book distinctly different from those
of former years. A number of cuts
of the new buildings at Homewood
will form an interesting feature of
the annual.

*

*

*

The Trinity College Y. M. C. A.
is raising money to put an ambulance in the war zone. They already have over two hundred dollars pledged.
.\1. I. T. has instituted this year
the carrying on of "fraternity
forums." Four of the fraternities
have had successful business men
of Boston give them informal talks.
The students of Syracuse University are planting trees on their
campus. Fifty men work at a time
under the supervision of some of
the instructors.
* * *
Northwestern College freshmen
are still permitted to cover their
heads according to their own individual tastes. But the Student
Council has recently written to
some of the other colleges to make
inquiries into the advisability of instituting a freshman cap rtile.
Green skull caps will probably be
prescribed.
* * *
Students at Michigan Agricultural College are considering a
Class Constitution, embodying all
the present customs of class government. This is a good measure,
calculated to do away with confusion and to standardize procedure. and would do well here.

Ben Tappan, who appeared for
.his last time, as he is completing his
eighth year at the University, and
receives his degree in medicine this
June, once again starred brilliantly,
winning 22 points in five events.
He took first place in the 120-yard
hurdles in 16.seconds; first place in
the pole vault at 10 feet; first place
in the broad jump with 22 feet iY2
inches; tied for first with Captain
Connolly in the high jump, at 5 feet
inches, and took second place in
the low hurdles, won by Schultz,
W. and L., in 26 seconds. This
completes a wonderful record in
scoring for Tappan, who has placed
in every event he has entered this
year, and made a total of nearly
ioo points in seven meets. He will
be sorely missed next year.
Fred.' Hall, of Hopkins, was the
second figure in brilliance. He
made tell points by winning both the
quarter and the half-mile.

victory and his "H," was a, great
